learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate a knowledge of, and an ability to identify and recall the fundamental principles and rules of, property law.
Identify and apply property-law principles in analysing particular factual situations.
Analyse and interpret relevant case law and statutes relating to property law.
Demonstrate skills in legal research (including an ability to identify and locate relevant literature) and demonstrate skills in written communication (including organising and structuring ideas).
Reflect upon the social implications of rules of property and critically evaluate common justifications for property rights.

assessments.task_description:
Submission of handwritten notes (1-2 A4 pages) on the tutorial questions for each of the 10 tutorials.

Tutorial preparation ‘assessment’ will be in accordance with the following criteria:

  1. A student will be awarded 1.5 marks per tutorial by attending the tutorial for its entire duration and, at the beginning of the tutorial, submitting to the tutor, handwritten notes on the questions scheduled to be discussed in the tutorial for that week.
  2. The assessment is pass/fail. A pass will mean that 1.5 marks will be allocated per tutorial, to a maximum of 10 marks. The criterion for passing is whether, in the opinion of your Tutor, you have made a reasonable and serious attempt to answer the tutorial exercise. In so doing, students must attempt to: (1) identify the issues raided by the question(s); (2) identify the rules and/or principles relevant to answering the issues; (3) identify and relate to the issues the relevant facts and/or factual assumptions; and (4) raise and address and matters of relevant legal policy were necessary or desirable.
  3. While collaboration, i.e. oral discussion of the questions, is acceptable, it is expected that any notes submitted for marking will reflect independent thought and judgement. Copying notes from other students is not acceptable and may be treated as academic misconduct. If there is genuine collaboration resulting in similar notes, you are advised to indicate the name(s) of your collaborator(s).
  4. Note that the feedback for this piece of assessment will be the tutorial itself, ie. the one to which the preparation relates. The answers will not be returned with comments, and so students should take the opportunity to raise any questions during the tutorial.
  5. At the end of the semester, a mark out of 10 will be given to each student if, in the overall judgement of the course coordinator, the criteria set out in the course profile have been satisfied.
  6. Answers cannot be submitted after class, or by email, or by another student on your behalf. Students must attend the tutorial with their answers and stay for the duration of the tutorial to receive any marks. A student will not obtain a mark for tutorial preparation if she or he does not attend the tutorial group in which she or he is enrolled.
  7. The maximum mark can be achieved by submitting seven times in the course of the semester. Students can be absent or not prepare four times and still gain the full marks for tutorial preparation. This is designed to accommodate emergencies and other reasons for non-preparation.
  8. Students should not email the Course Coordinator regarding special requests for non-preparation except in the exceptional case where the student is unable to attend tutorials over the entire semester.
  9. The tutorial in Week 1 is not assessable. Therefore, students cannot submit answers to this tutorial exercise. The content covered in this week's Tutorial is still potentially assessable in the In-Semester and End-of-Semester Examinations.

After enrolments close, students will not be permitted to change their enrolment in a tutorial without the written permission of the Course Coordinator.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Students are to hand their answers to their Tutor in person at the beginning of the relevant tutorial.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
The In-Semester Examination will be held on Monday 13 April 2026 at 6.00 pm in the UQ Centre, Learning Theatre (27A -220). Students should arrive by 5.45 pm and bring with them their Student ID cards. The date, time and venue are subject to confirmation. Therefore, students must keep up to date with this course's announcements on Learn.UQ. Please note that due to the size of the cohort, it will take time to check Student ID cards, mark attendance and collect exam materials. Students should not expect to depart the the exam venue until well after 7.30 pm.

Further information about the content, format and marking criteria of the In-Semester Examination will be provided on the course's Learn.UQ page once the Chief Examiner has approved the examination paper.

The Exam comprises 60 minutes working time and 10 minutes planning time. Further information will be posted to Learn.UQ.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
The End-of-semester examination will be held during end-of-semester examination period. Your personalised exam timetable available through your my.UQ homepage will provide full exam details for your scheduled exam.

The exam will comprise up to three questions, which may be compulsory. One or more of the questions may be broken down into individual parts. The examination paper will indicate the proportion of the marks given to each question (and to individual parts within a question where applicable). The examination paper may consist of problem-style and/or essay-style questions, or mixed problem- / essay-style questions, of varying weightings and length. Any of the questions may combine material from different aspects of the examinable topics in the course.

Further information about the content, format and marking criteria of the End-of-semester Examination will be provided on the course's Learn.UQ page once the Chief Examiner has approved the examination paper.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. This includes copying materials produced by AI to respond to exam questions. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.topic:
Lecture 1: What is property?

This lecture introduces students to the course. It sets out the course's expectations, activities and assessment structure. It introduces to the concept of 'property', as well as discussing the basic taxonomy of property law, its functions and characteristics, competing conceptions of property and statutory/common law definitions of property.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Lecture 1: What is property? This lecture introduces students to the course. It sets out the course's expectations, activities and assessment structure. It introduces to the concept of 'property', as well as discussing the basic taxonomy of property law, its functions and characteristics, competing conceptions of property and statutory/common law definitions of property.

learning_activities.topic:
Tutorial 1

This Tutorial helps students to classify different kinds of property. No prior knowledge is required. Students are not able to submit answers to this week's tutorial. The content covered in this week's Tutorial is still potentially assessable in the In-Semester and End-of-Semester Examinations.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Tutorial 1 This Tutorial helps students to classify different kinds of property. No prior knowledge is required. Students are not able to submit answers to this week's tutorial. The content covered in this week's Tutorial is still potentially assessable in the In-Semester and End-of-Semester Examinations.

learning_activities.topic:
Lecture 2: Personal Property Foundations

This lecture begins an examination of personal property, introducing students to the different forms of personal property, concepts of original and derivative title, various 'interests' in personal property including ownership and possession. It examines Romalpa clauses as a case study to show how ownership and possession can become fragmented.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Lecture 2: Personal Property Foundations This lecture begins an examination of personal property, introducing students to the different forms of personal property, concepts of original and derivative title, various 'interests' in personal property including ownership and possession. It examines Romalpa clauses as a case study to show how ownership and possession can become fragmented.

Tutorial 2

This Tutorial is based on Week 1's Lecture and materials.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05

learning_activities.topic:
Lecture 3: Personal Property Foundations (continued)

The Lecture will explore the concept of "possessory title": the nature, forms and elements of legal possession, and examine case studies in actual possession (finders and bailment).

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Lecture 3: Personal Property Foundations (continued) The Lecture will explore the concept of "possessory title": the nature, forms and elements of legal possession, and examine case studies in actual possession (finders and bailment).

learning_activities.topic_description: Tutorial 3 This Tutorial is based on week 2's Lecture and material.

learning_activities.topic:
Lecture 4: Personal Property Foundations (continued)

This Lecture continue to explore the modern law of bailment, including sub-bailments and how bailments are terminated. It also examines the 'property' torts of detinue, conversion, and trespass.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Lecture 4: Personal Property Foundations (continued) This Lecture continue to explore the modern law of bailment, including sub-bailments and how bailments are terminated. It also examines the 'property' torts of detinue, conversion, and trespass.

The Tutorial is based on Week 3's Lecture and materials.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Tutorial 4 The Tutorial is based on Week 3's Lecture and materials.

learning_activities.topic:
Lecture 5: Personal Property Foundations (continued)

This Lecture looks at the principles governing the passing of title to goods under the Sale of Goods Act 1896 (Qld), including the nature and formation of the contract of sale, the general transfer rules and the nemo dat rule and its exceptions.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Lecture 5: Personal Property Foundations (continued) This Lecture looks at the principles governing the passing of title to goods under the Sale of Goods Act 1896 (Qld), including the nature and formation of the contract of sale, the general transfer rules and the nemo dat rule and its exceptions.

learning_activities.topic:
Lecture 6: The Personal Property / Real Property Interface

This Lecture examines the personal property/real property interface, specifically: when does an item of personal property become 'land'?

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L05

learning_activities.topic:
Lecture 7: Real Property Foundations

This Lecture examines the concept of 'land', both its physical and conceptual characteristics (including boundaries), statutory remedies for mistake of title and encroachment, and briefly introduces the concept of Crown land. It also examines the doctrines of tenures and estates.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Lecture 7: Real Property Foundations This Lecture examines the concept of 'land', both its physical and conceptual characteristics (including boundaries), statutory remedies for mistake of title and encroachment, and briefly introduces the concept of Crown land. It also examines the doctrines of tenures and estates.

learning_activities.topic:
Lecture 8: Real Property Foundations (continued)

The Lecture examines the nature and creation of legal and equitable interests in land, including 'formalities'. It also introduces students to the Torrens system of land registration by starting with its history and early development.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Lecture 8: Real Property Foundations (continued) The Lecture examines the nature and creation of legal and equitable interests in land, including 'formalities'. It also introduces students to the Torrens system of land registration by starting with its history and early development.

learning_activities.topic:
Lecture 9: Real Property Foundations (continued)

This Lecture continues our examination of the Torrens system of land registration, discusses the concept of indefeasibility and the fraud exception, among other things.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Lecture 9: Real Property Foundations (continued) This Lecture continues our examination of the Torrens system of land registration, discusses the concept of indefeasibility and the fraud exception, among other things.

learning_activities.topic:
Lecture 10: Real Property Foundations (continued)

The Lecture will continue with the topic of exceptions to Indefeasibility: in personam exception; short lease, omitted easement and adverse possession exceptions.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L05

learning_activities.topic:
Lecture 11: Real Property Foundations (continued)

This Lecture looks at correction of the register, overriding statutes, compensation. It also examines how unregistered interests interact with the Torrens system, as well as caveats and priorities.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L05
